awd_abstract_narration:
Cosmic gas flows accompanying galaxy formation have high velocities, span enormous scales, and are highly turbulent, but the effects of turbulence on galaxy formation and associated processes are still largely unexplored.  This project is a systematic exploration of turbulence and its effects on the observable properties of galaxies using self-consistent and realistic high-resolution cosmological simulations.  It will address several fundamental issues in the interpretation of observations of galaxies across cosmic time.  The Adler Planetarium will use high-fidelity, scientifically-accurate visualizations of the planned simulations suitable for full-dome projectors.  These visualizations will be available to other planetaria, and for online streaming and viewing with the increasingly widespread virtual reality headsets, which can provide a new and effective way to reach broad segments of society, including students and educators, showing the results of cutting-edge research in an engaging and easily accessible form.

The work is enabled by a recent implementation of subgrid turbulence by this team, and will (1) investigate whether slip sheet instabilities develop in cold gas accretion flows, and the effect of turbulence on key properties; (2) explore gravitational instability and stellar feedback in driving turbulence; (3) quantify how turbulence affects the density structure of gas, pressure support, star formation, and mixing processes; and (4) explore models of the initial mass function (IMF) of stars.  The methods use a model of efficient and multi-faceted feedback, including feedback due to cosmic rays, formation of molecular hydrogen, chemical enrichment and evolution, and radiative transfer of ionizing and far-ultra-violet radiation.  The study explores key issues, including the processes controlling gas supply to galaxies, the environmental dependence of star and star cluster formation efficiency, and the IMF in galaxies of different stellar masses, metallicities, morphologies, and star formation histories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Whenever there is a fluid in rapid motion, whether here on Earth or in space, there will be turbulence - chaotic flow characterized by random disturbances of velocity and gas density. We can hear these disturbances any time we hear wind noise in our ears. Cosmic gas flows accompanying formation of galaxies such as our Milky Way have high velocities, span enormous scales, and are highly turbulent, but the effects of turbulence on galaxy formation and associated processes are still poorly understood. The goal of this project was a systematic exploration of turbulence and its effects on the observable properties of galaxies. This was done using both observational data and theoretical models and simulations. 

At the beginning of the project, we focused on understanding how turbulent motions contribute to the support of gaseous halos surrounding galaxies. This work helped us clarify the role of turbulence in balancing dynamics of gas falling onto galaxies. We also examined how turbulence shapes pressure distribution within galactic disks using advanced simulations that incorporated models of star formation, stellar feedback, and cosmic rays. 

We expanded this work subsequently along several investigative directions. These ranged from theoretical studies of gas dynamics and shocks in galaxy clusters to analyzing how gas cools and evolves around galaxies similar to the Milky Way. We also tested a new turbulence-based star formation model and developed an innovative numerical method for simulating turbulence. Despite pandemic-related travel restrictions, we presented our findings in online seminars and workshops, ensuring collaboration and knowledge-sharing. We also shared cutting-edge results in galaxy formation in public talks in the Chicago area. 

We achieved a significant breakthrough in the second half of this project. Analyzing computer simulations of galaxy formation and observations of low-metallicity stars in the Milky Way, we have discovered a previously unknown population of stars in the Milky Way, which we named "Aurora." These stars formed in the early, turbulent stages of our Galaxy before its disk took shape. This discovery opened new avenues for exploring the early history of the Milky Way. 

We also developed a new model for dwarf galaxy evolution, which we tested against a wide range of observations. This model became a versatile tool for studying star formation, cluster formation, and feedback processes in both dwarf galaxies and larger galaxies like the Milky Way.

In the final stage of the project, we built on these findings, delving deeper into the early stages of the Milky Way’s evolution. Our analysis of low-metallicity stars showed that a significant portion of star formation in this period occurred in massive star clusters. These clusters played a crucial role in enriching the interstellar medium and left distinct chemical signatures. We also continued refining our dwarf galaxy model, using it to interpret new ultraviolet observations and predict future discoveries with the James Webb Space Telescope. 

We explored how star formation efficiency varies across different galactic environments using controlled computer simulations. We showed that the simulations reproduce a remarkable universality of the characteristic value of the efficiency deduced from observations. Based on our analyses, we showed that gas turbulence is a key process regulating star formation in galaxies and is the origin of the observed universality of star formation in galaxies. 

Throughout the project, we made important strides in understanding the turbulent and dynamic processes shaping galaxies, from the smallest dwarfs to the Milky Way itself. Our results have shed light on how turbulence influences star formation, the structure of gaseous halos, and the evolution of galaxies over cosmic time. This work has also provided a solid foundation for future studies and models in galaxy formation and evolution.
